sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Complete rupture of the medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) during traumatic patellar dislocation may contribute to further patellar instability. As there is still no consensus regarding indications for treatment of such injuries, data on exact localization and extent of tear may influence the treatment decisions.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: Analysis of the patterns and the age-related differences in the distribution of medial patellofemoral ligament injury during traumatic patellar dislocation in children and adolescents.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Fifty consecutive patients aged 10.5 to 17.5 years were operated on for injuries after a first episode of traumatic patellar dislocation. The indications for surgery were osteochondral fracture and/or complete MPFL tear. Medial patellofemoral ligament injuries were assessed preoperatively by sonography and then verified at surgery. To assess the influence of skeletal maturity on the injury pattern, the cohort was subdivided into 2 subgroups: skeletally immature and skeletally mature. Distribution of MPFL injuries in both groups was compared.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Medial patellofemoral ligament injury was present at surgery in 94% of cases, most commonly at the patellar attachment (66%), followed by mid-fibers (50%) and femoral attachment (32%). In 46%, it occurred in more than 1 localization. Based on functional status of the ligament during dynamic ultrasound examination, 2 types of injury were distinguished: complete and partial rupture. Eighteen of 21 complete ruptures were localized at the patellar attachment, and all but 1 case had a form of the avulsion fracture. Age-related analysis revealed these differences in the incidence of MPFL injury in all 3 localizations comparing skeletally immature with skeletally mature patients: 79% vs 54% at the patellar attachment, 46% vs 54% at the mid-fiber region, and 33% vs 31% at the femoral attachment. Nevertheless, the only statistically significant difference was the higher incidence of patellar attachment injury in the skeletally immature group (P = .029). Sonography demonstrated more than 90% accuracy and predictive value in assessing pathoanatomy as well as the functional status of the medial patellofemoral ligament.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Medial patellofemoral ligament injury patterns vary in skeletally immature patients compared with skeletally mature patients. Sonography proved high reliability as a diagnostic tool in traumatic patellar dislocation.

body.p: The medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) is considered the most important soft tissue restraint providing medial stability of the patellofemoral joint.5,7,38 During traumatic patellar dislocation (TPD), the MPFL is subjected to severe stretching forces, resulting in injuries of the ligament in most patients.1,2,18,47,48 Posttraumatic insufficiency of the MPFL contributes to chronic medial patellar instability, which may lead to recurrent patellar dislocations (reported in 15%-44% of cases after a first TPD episode),4,15,44 impairing the function of the patellofemoral joint and, in longer perspective, accelerating osteoarthritic changes.11,12,21,28,29,32,44

Despite data currently emerging and questioning the long-term benefits from an acute MPFL repair as routine management of first-time TPD in every patient,‡ a complete ligament tear is still considered by many authors an indication for early surgery.4,11,44 Therefore, the localization and extent of MPFL injury are important factors that should be taken under consideration in a decision on the treatment strategy. Consequently, precise diagnosis of MPFL status after TPD seems to be of significant clinical value.

Numerous reports, based mainly on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), proved a high incidence of MPFL injuries during TPD, but conflicting data on localization and the extent of the MPFL tears have accumulated over the years. Some authors have emphasized the patellar attachment to be the most frequent site of injury,8,14,17,47,48 whereas others have reported injury of the ligament’s middle part (mid-fibers)18,19,27 or its femoral attachment1,6,37,41 to be most common.

Moreover, MRI cannot routinely provide dynamic real-time evaluation. In addition, the oblique course of the ligament not parallel to the standard planes used for knee MRI may make unambiguous diagnosis difficult in some cases. Therefore, assessment of the functional status of MPFL after its injury may be challenging. That was pointed out by many authors who encountered problems in distinguishing on MRI complete MPFL rupture, which may be considered an indication for acute surgical repair, from partial rupture, treated nonoperatively as a rule in the acute phase.1,8,18,47

Recently, ultrasonography (US) has increasingly been applied as a diagnostic tool for the knee extensor mechanism—its capability to provide real-time static and dynamic examinations allows accurate investigation of the whole course of MPFL fibers and detection of posttraumatic anatomic abnormalities as well as functional impairment of the ligament.9,10,34,46

Despite the fact that the incidence of TPD is the highest in teenagers (29/100,000 per year in the 10- to 17-year-old group vs <10/100,000 per year in the overall population),4,12,23 most available studies on MPFL injury patterns in TPD are focused on adult or mixed cohorts.8,14,18,27,47 Limited and confusing data are available on possible differences in MPFL injury patterns between adults and children/adolescents.1,17,24,48

Using US scanning for initial, visual assessment of MPFL injuries, with further surgical verification and confirmation, we decided to present this study with the following aims: (1) to analyze MPFL injury patterns in children and adolescents after an acute first-time TPD episode, (2) to compare these patterns in skeletally immature and skeletally mature patients, and (3) secondarily, to assess the accuracy of US scanning of the MPFL.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: This is a retrospective analysis of data prospectively collected between 2004 and 2011 in a single, academic pediatric trauma surgery department. The inclusion criteria were as follows: patients with acute knee hemarthrosis after the first TPD episode, treated surgically as an urgent case, on the basis of clinical and US findings before surgery. All surgeries were done by the authors of the present publication. Before surgery, all patients underwent standard radiographic examination of the injured knee (anteroposterior, lateral, and Merchant views) followed by US examination according to the Kellner and Reimers16 protocol. All US examinations were performed on the day of admission by a single examiner (J.F., trained in musculoskeletal ultrasonography, with more than 10 years of experience), using an ATL HDI 3500 scanner and 5- to 12-MHz, 38-mm linear array (ATL Ultrasound, Bothell, Washington). Both knees were examined, and US images of corresponding knee structures were compared (including MPFL, medial patellotibial ligament, vastus medialis obliquus muscle, patellar ligament) using the scans of the uninjured side as a reference. For detailed assessment and description of injuries, MPFL was divided into 3 topographical parts, which were scanned separately for injury signs: patellar attachment, mid-fibers region, and femoral attachment.

In all knees, dynamic US examination as described previously9,10 supplemented standard US protocol for assessing the functional status of the MPFL. Based on both those examinations, the MPFL injuries were classified into 2 types:

list-item.p: Complete ruptures, resulting in acute posttraumatic MPFL insufficiency: the criterion for diagnosis of this injury type was the presence of a full-thickness MPFL tear in any localization, creating a ≥5-mm gap between the torn fragments of the ligament on static US examination or during maneuver of manual lateralization of the patella on dynamic examination.
Partial ruptures: all other MPFL injuries not fulfilling above described criteria.

sec.p: Indications for urgent surgical treatment were based on the results of clinical and US findings and included (1) sonographic evidence of type I MPFL injury according to the above definition, with acute anatomic MPFL repairs done in those cases, and (2) the presence of a floating loose body after osteochondral fracture inside the joint. Loose bodies considered eligible for fixation (the smallest diameter of a subchondral bony fragment 8 mm or more and its adequate thickness) were reduced and stabilized in situ via a mini-arthrotomy approach. Loose bodies not suitable for reduction were removed arthroscopically and the edges of the bed were debrided.

Injuries of the MPFL patellar attachment and mid-fibers region detected on US scan were verified in all cases during surgery (via arthroscopy or arthrotomy). The femoral attachment was surgically explored in all patients who underwent acute MPFL repairs, when surgical approach allowed for direct examination of this region. In the remaining cases, femoral attachment was assessed sonographically by comparison with the contralateral uninjured side.

Fifty consecutive patients met the inclusion criteria: 20 girls and 30 boys aged 14.75 years on average at the time of injury (range, 10.5-17.5 years). There were 23 right and 27 left knees affected. To analyze the influence of age on the patterns of MPFL injuries, we subdivided the cohort into 2 subgroups based on the radiological signs of skeletal maturity (presence of active physeal plates on routine knee radiographs taken on the day of the injury): the first subgroup included 24 cases (11 girls and 13 boys) aged 11.5 to 15 years at the time of injury (representing skeletal immaturity), and a second subgroup included 26 cases (9 girls and 17 boys) aged 14 to 17.5 years at the time of injury (representing skeletally maturity or close to skeletal maturity).

To accomplish the aims of our study, we analyzed and/or quantified the following parameters: (1) localization and shape of the tear, (2) quantity and morphologic characteristics of single and multiple MPFL injuries, (3) quantity and morphologic characteristics of partial and complete ruptures, (4) age-related injury pattern differences, and (5) accuracy and predictive value of US examination in determining MPFL injuries during TPD.

The incidence of MPFL injuries in each localization was compared between the 2 age-related subgroups using the χ2 1-tailed test to find possible differences. A P value of <.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Overall, 74 localizations of MPFL injuries were present in 47 of 50 patients (94%). In 3 patients, no obvious MPFL injury was diagnosed.

The patellar attachment was affected most commonly (n = 33 patients) (Table 1), and 94% (31 cases) had a form of avulsion fracture of the medial patellar border (Figure 1). There were single and multifocal injuries to the MPFL in 24 and 23 patients, respectively (Table 2). Type I MPFL injuries (complete ruptures) were found in 21 patients (42%) (Table 3). Eleven of those 21 complete MPFL ruptures (52.4%) were limited to single localization; the remaining 10 (47.6%) represented multifocal MPFL injuries, but in all 10 cases, the gap of 5 mm or more between torn fibers of the ligament, typical for type I injury, was present in only 1 dominant tear. Injuries to the MPFL in the remaining 26 patients were classified as type II (partial ruptures).

sec.p: Statistical analysis showed a significantly higher incidence of patellar attachment injury in the skeletally immature (P = .029). There was no significant difference in other types and locations of the MPFL injuries between the 2 subgroups.

Macroscopic confirmation of sonographic findings (including complete MPFL rupture in type I injuries or bruises along MPFL fibers without any detectable gap, indicating partial rupture in type II injuries) was possible for all MPFL patellar attachments and mid-fibers tears (via arthroscopy or arthrotomy). For sonographically stated femoral MPFL attachment tears, direct intraoperative confirmation was possible in 5 patients (out of 21 who underwent open MPFL repair, in whom the extent of the surgery allowed exploring the femoral attachment), whereas the remaining 11 femoral attachment tears were confirmed indirectly, by a comparison with the US images of the contralateral, uninjured knee, used as a reference.

The dynamic US examination allowed visualizing adequately the functional status of the MPFL in all but 1 patient (Table 5). False-positive sonographic diagnosis of complete MPFL rupture in the mid-fibers region on dynamic US was done in this case. Surgical open exploration revealed macroscopic signs of MPFL mid-fibers injury, but its complete rupture was not confirmed.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The optimal therapy for acute, first-episode TPD is still a subject of continued discussion in the orthopaedic literature: there is no consensus regarding surgical versus nonsurgical management, emergency versus elective surgery, anatomic repair versus augmentation (ligamentoraphy), or reconstruction of the medial patellar retinaculum.§ There is, however, agreement that the main structure to be repaired/reconstructed remains the MPFL, as a main restraint against lateral patellar dislocation.2-5,7,27,30,44 Therefore, the site and severity of MPFL injuries, as well as their possible functional consequences for patellar stability, should undergo precise diagnosis, results of which may contribute to the choice of the treatment strategy. There are significant data on the patterns of MPFL injury in TPD based on MRI findings in adults‖ as well as in pediatric groups,1,17,48 but presented results are equivocal; there are significant differences in the reported distribution of MPFL injuries (Tables 6 and 7).

sec.p: Those confusing data concerning the localization and extent of the MPFL injury after TPD may be related to several factors: lack of a precise definition of a complete MPFL rupture given in MRI studies,14,27,48 inability to demonstrate the dynamic status of the ligament after a TPD episode on routine MRI scans, and oblique course of the ligament’s fibers in relation to standard planes used for knee MRI, making it difficult for evaluation in many cases.1,8 Those factors cause problems in distinguishing on MRI between severe MPFL sprain and its total rupture, which may result subsequently in functional insufficiency.18,47 Moreover, the criteria for inclusion to the above-cited studies and verification of MRI findings were not uniform (eg, average time of follow-up, average time from injury to the examination, age of analyzed patients, lack or small number of patients undergoing surgical verification).

Contemporary ultrasonography, aided with digital image rendering, allows for a high-definition, precise, real-time soft tissue visualization. This diagnostic modality also has been successfully used to assess the sequelae of TPD, but to date, only a few studies have reported on the intact MPFL images and its injury patterns detected by means of US. Starok et al,43 followed by Phornphutkul et al,36 in cadaveric studies described the appearance of the intact anatomic MPFL. Trikha et al46 analyzed MPFL injuries with further surgical correlation in 10 patients and reported patellar and femoral attachment injuries in 8 and 3 cases, respectively. Avulsion fractures of the medial patellar border were observed, but the exact frequency of this specific injury was not reported.

O’Reilly et al34 analyzed sonographic appearances of the MPFL injury in 30 patients with surgical verification in 10 of them. They reported a 77% overall incidence of MPFL injury, with single localization in 60% of cases (33% patellar attachment injuries and 27% femoral attachment injuries) and multifocal localization in 17% (both attachments); 47% of the patellar attachment injuries had a form of avulsion fracture of the medial patellar border; and 61% of all MPFL injuries were classified as complete ruptures, but the exact definition of this specific condition was not given. Surgical exploration of MPFL injuries in 10 of 30 patients confirmed all US findings.

Our results confirm the high accuracy of sonography in assessing MPFL injuries (Table 5). The MPFL was easily detectable on US examination: the ligament, which lies superficially, was accessible in all regions to sonographic scanning in any plane. Sonographic patterns of different MPFL injuries were highly characteristic and easily verified via comparison with the corresponding areas of the uninjured knee. The possibility of direct diagnosis of the functional status of the MPFL during dynamic examination, while manually moving the patella laterally or/and medially, gave another important advantage. By modifying the classic classification of ligamentous injuries into sprains, partial tears, and ruptures,22 which do not necessarily reflect the injured ligament’s function, we propose subdividing sonographic diagnoses of MPFL injuries into 2 types: complete, considered unstable (type I), or partial (type II), despite the location of the tear (Figures 1 and 2). The minimum of a 5-mm distention between torn ends of the ligament in any location during static or dynamic US examination was defined as a borderline criterion distinguishing between the above-defined 2 types. Because the classification of MPFL injuries into partial and complete tears, even if used, has not been previously well defined, or the definition has been given based on the assessment of the MRI scans (static examination),1,8,14,17-19,48 no data are available in the literature to support a cutoff criterion distinguishing between those 2 functional types of MPFL injury on a US scan. Therefore, for the purposes of the present analysis, the distance of 5 mm between torn ligament ends (whether on static or dynamic examination) was established as a cutoff value to classify the MPFL injury as partial or complete, similar to the classification of other knee ligamentous instabilities (eg, anterior instability after ACL injury with a 5-mm difference between the affected and contralateral knee during Lachman maneuver is considered a first-degree instability). Further prospective studies are required to assess whether and how those sonographic subtypes influence treatment strategies for TPD.

sec.p: Another advantage worth emphasizing is the ease of performing ultrasound in a young patient with an acutely swollen knee. We have not encountered any problems related to pain, anxiety, or a patient’s noncompliance. There was no need to repeat the US examination in the operating room with the patient under anesthesia to obtain a proper diagnosis.

The protocol of the present study focused on describing the consequences of patellar dislocation on anatomic and functional status of MPFL and, to our knowledge, was based on the largest surgically verified group of patients. Because of inclusion criteria, we were able to assess not only complete injuries to the MPFL that required surgery but also those MPFL tears (type II) that hypothetically could be treated nonoperatively; they were seen and quantified during surgeries done for other indications (osteochondral fractures care). As a result, we acquired abundant data on the pathoanatomy and localization of MPFL tears. In addition, in contrast to most previous studies reporting on adults, our data concerned children and adolescents, who remain the age group being the most prone to patellar dislocations.

Our sonographic and surgical observations confirmed that MPFL injury is almost always found after an acute TPD episode, being located most frequently at the patellar attachment followed by mid-fibers. This confirms data presented by other authors.6,8,17,47,48 Although the rate of patellar attachment and mid-fibers injuries was similar, type I ruptures were found at the patellar attachment in most cases (85.7% vs 9.5%) (Table 3). The femoral attachment injury in our cohort occurred in 32% cases, but only in 1 case was the tear in this localization diagnosed as a type I injury and consequently required surgical repair; these findings correlated well with the results presented by Nomura et al27 and Guerrero et al14 but remained in contrast to other reports, which pointed to a higher frequency of MPFL injuries in this localization (Table 6).6,14,27,37 In all but 2 cases in the analyzed group, the patellar attachment injury had a form of avulsion fracture of the medial patellar border with a thin sleeve of bony fragment attached to the ligament fibers (Figure 1B), and such a high frequency of avulsion fractures of the medial patellar border in TPD had not yet been reported.13,18,19,23,27,34,45 We suppose that this frequent occurrence of avulsion patellar fractures might be related to the age of our patients. As described by Ogden33 and Stanitski et al,42 the medial patellar border, constituting the patellar attachment of the MPFL, remains cartilaginous until age 16 to 18 years, in contrast to the distal femoral epiphysis (femoral MPFL attachment), which ossifies earlier, usually at age 13 to 15 years. This chondro-osseous boundary is susceptible to tension forces resulting in avulsion fractures rather than MPFL tears during a TPD episode. Grogan et al13 described sleeve fractures at the medial border of the patella as characteristic for adolescents before completing the patellar ossification process, with further abnormal enchondral parapatellar ossifications resulting from abruption of the cartilaginous-perichondrial/periosteal fragments. Those calcified medial parapatellar masses were also considered a pathognomonic sign of a previous TPD episode.45 To support the hypothesis of an age influence on the patellar attachment injury patterns, we subdivided the cohort into 2 age-related groups, representing skeletally immature and skeletally mature cases; MPFL injury patterns were analyzed in both groups and compared (Table 1). Analysis revealed a statistically significant higher incidence of the patellar attachment injury (avulsion fracture) in the younger group than in the older group (P = .029). The above-presented data can perhaps explain differences in previous reports, based on mixed-age cohorts, on the incidence of the localization of MPFL injuries. During growth, the patellar attachment with avulsion fracture remains the most frequent result of TPD, whereas in skeletally mature patients, the incidence of injuries to the other MPFL areas, especially the femoral attachment, may increase.

Interestingly, injuries to the MPFL may occur simultaneously in more than 1 area of the ligament.1,6,8,11,14,17,37 Our results also confirmed these data and, moreover, that such multiple injuries were quite frequent, being present in almost half of all the described injuries (46%). Nevertheless, in those cases that required surgical intervention, a dominant (complete) tear was found in only 1 localization, and surgery was addressed to repair this significant injury.

We are aware of some limitations of the present study. First, the surgeons were not blind to ultrasound scan results that had been done before. This overlap carries a potential for interpretation bias regarding the accuracy of the ultrasonography. Nevertheless, the results on the distribution and extent of the MPFL injuries, constituting the primary aim of the present analysis, were calculated exclusively based on macroscopic findings during surgery. Second, our observations on femoral MPFL attachment were not always confirmed by surgical exploration. We think, however, that the data could be reliably supported by detailed US examination and routine comparison to the images obtained from the opposite, unaffected side. In our hands, the injury of the MPFL femoral attachment, if it had occurred, was always obvious and easy to define on US scans by the presence of ligamentous edema (thickening, decreasing of echogenicity, disturbance of typical laminar structure), elevation of the fibers from the bony attachment, and/or periligamentous fluid collection (hematoma) (Figure 3A); this pattern was invariably different in comparison with an unaffected MPFL attachment in the area of the medial femoral epicondyle (thin, multilaminar structure tangent to the bone) (Figure 3B).

Note the thickening of the attachment: edema (solid arrowheads), decreased echogenicity of the fibers (arrow), and surrounding paraligamentous fluid collection (open arrowhead). (B) Normal femoral MPFL attachment to the medial femoral epicondyle (the same patient, contralateral side).

list-item.p: Injury to the MPFL occurred in 94% of children and adolescents after first-time, acute TPD, being multifocal in almost half of the cases. Total MPFL ruptures, potentially requiring surgical repair, were present in 42%.

Injury patterns in skeletally immature adolescents vary significantly from those in adults, particularly regarding higher frequency of patellar attachment tears in the younger group, which usually has a form of a sleeve fracture of the medial patellar border.
Sonographic anatomic and functional assessment of MPFL injuries has a high rate of correspondence to surgical findings.
